title: How to do research independently and publish it on my own - Quora

response.answer_text: Great answers by Hadayat Seddiqi , Marcia J. Bates and Joseph Wang Okay, many are and will continue to say that you NEED an advisor, that you NEED funding , that you NEED a lab to be associated with, that you NEED a professor to guide you. Is that really true?  Nikola Tesla - One of the earliest independent scientists Lets back up for a moment - what is a research paper after all?[1] A research paper is the culmination and final product of an involved process of research, critical thinking, source evaluation, organization, and composition. There is research, critical thinking, evaluation, organization and composition. I don’t see any other “have to’s” here! What you NEED to do, though? Read a lot of research in your domain.If you have read a lot of papers, you know what is considered an idea worth publishing. Again, your idea need not be path breaking to begin with. Any idea requires nourishment before it can be presented. So take your basic ideas and spend more time working on them. Identify different possibilities, test them out, record the tests for your reference later. Go back and read more.Keep your notes and results organized in one place. This will be the base on which you will be writing your research paper on. There are a lot of tools to aggregate all your sources and references.Identify a journal in your domain - is there something specific like the American Chemical Society or American Physical Society? There are always the generic but popular ones like Elsevier, Wiley etc. Find out what kind of papers are published in these journals, what is the level of quality you have to attain to get published. You can always submit to an another journal if your paper gets rejected. And when that happens, you will not be the first researcher to get rejected before getting published :)Against usual advice, start writing as you research. In this amazing talk, Simon Peyton Jones from Microsoft Research explains how writing can quick start your thought process on your research. Writing can help you think through your arguments and present a formidable case. You can quickly get started with a MS Word template.There’s a lot of grey areas to presenting your research to an advisor - there are some who can genuinely help you and others who just want a name on your paper as a co-author. Better than an advisor, get a mentor. Someone who has been there, done that aka published a paper.Use tools available to weed out unwanted parts of your research process. For example, for following author guidelines and formatting, try Typeset - it automatically applies all the rules on your content in a click. You can use a reference library such as Mendeley to discover and collect all your references as you research. So when you are ready to write your paper you can quickly get your sources in a click. If your research workflow is online you can also use Paperpile.Now, this is in no way comprehensive. Research cannot be comprehended in a Quora post. Get started, you will find your way through :) In case you want to read more - What are useful tools for writing academic papersHow to write a great research paperHow to write an effective research paper…The top 100 papersWhat are the steps to follow for writing a research paper?Footnotes [1] Purdue OWL

The first step is to read about and understand a topic. If you were an undergrad and you asked a professor for a research problem, he'd throw some papers and books at you and tell you to get lost for 2 weeks (or a month, or a semester, or a year). So if you wanted to go about doing it yourself, you'll want to pick your problems wisely since you don't want to bite off more than you can chew, especially if you have no guidance from someone who has done it all before. Thinking about it now, it will probably be difficult for most to do research completely on your own. It will probably take you much longer than it would if you had some guidance. The upshot to it is that your understanding is yours alone, and if you don't understand something then you should be working as hard as you can to alleviate that. And that work is what might make you better than peers who had advisors that helped them a lot. Not that one is better than another, or anything like that. Different strokes you know. If I were you, I'd try to contact some professors around your area, or failing that, just some professors or researchers anywhere. Ask them about their problem, maybe visit them and have a chat, and ask if there is a small project that you could work on. Researchers always have a million ideas, but they don't have the time to figure out which ones suck. They will probably be happy to have some free labor, and you'll gain your experience and maybe a recommendation letter too. There are some things you can do that are not really, truly considered core research, but would help you when you are doing research and would be good to know. For example, contributing to the Scientific Python project or an open-source CFD or astrophysics code would help you to understand how people write these codes and how to make your own contribution. Maybe there is a method not yet implemented in SciPy, or there is a newer algorithm that makes some operation faster. You can get the publication about it and translate it into fast Python code and contribute it. That's a really cool and easy way to understand research better. Most of research is just reading and understanding, so if you can read a paper and then do some real things with it and show that it works, that is making progress. It might be easier to suggest more specific topics if you mentioned what your interests are. CS is pretty broad.

Step 1: Know what you’re talking about. Make sure that you have read extensively on a topic. Make sure that you are comfortable with all the basic concepts related to your topic of interest. Most people do this by going to school or by working in the area. Either of these methods ensure that you can get to know which resources are trustworthy, and you get a network of people with relevant experience to leverage. If you have not done either of these things, it’s going to make it much more likely that you will be taken in by poorly researched, or invalidated by experience, publications. This can waste your time, and if you try to build on some of this bad data, may damage your reputation with publishers. I highly recommend that if you do not have formal education in the topic or do not work in the area, find respected subject matter experts to discuss your ideas with long before ever writing a paper. In addition to helping you avoid common misconceptions, this method can also help you gain acceptance as a serious researcher. Step 2: Be able to access or purchase necessary equipment. In addition to simply needing to have enough time to pursue your independent research while still being able to make sufficient money to eat, you will also need to be able to access the appropriate equipment. Depending on the type of research you are doing, this equipment can be quite expensive. The research and development firm where I work has over $30 million worth of equipment which I can access. Although much of this equipment is for use in areas I don’t work with, I regularly use around $3 million worth, including a CT scanner, a laser, servo controlled ultrasonic and spin welders, and very high quality microscopes. It would be really difficult (or impossible) to do the same quality of research if I had to be self funded. If your topic of interest doesn’t require expensive equipment, that’s helpful. You might think about if you can get a wealthy philanthropist or investor to help you with equipment. But, in that case, you have to consider why they should fund you, what do you bring to the table that other, more established researchers, don’t? Step 3: Do good research Obviously, right? Make sure your research is novel and very well documented. Documentation and detail are critical! Write down everything you do, even if you think it can’t possibly be important. Believe me, things I did not think were important, but documented anyway, have saved me many times when going back later to do follow up work. Also, be sure that you are not duplicating work that has been done before. It’s very important to do a really thorough literature search before getting started. Spend lots of time reading and taking notes, and make sure you understand what you read so you can apply it or reference it later. Step 4: Publish Now, the big payoff, getting published. Every journal will have unique formatting requirements and topic areas. While doing your literature review you should have gained a good idea of which journals would be best to approach with your new work. Write up your research in your chosen journals format. Get someone, anyone really, to read it over and check for poor word choice, poor grammar, or other glaring errors that you, as the author, will tend to glaze over. If you have developed a relationship with another researcher in the area, get them to review it. Then submit! Every journal will try to get you sign off some specific copy right agreement. Make sure to read and understand what you are agreeing to. My company has a group of librarians on staff who review these agreements and tell us whether we should sign or not. You’ll just have you. Do your best. Good luck!

To a certain extent, WHY you are doing the research project often determines the the methodology of your research. If your research project is based on your own curiosity, the first step MAY be gathering and collating data. IF you research project is for either a term paper, even a short essay, or master's thesis or a Ph.D. dissertation, the first step is t library research  BEFORE you write the proposal for your thesis or dissertation.  First step for writing a term paper or research paper is to make an outline. if you keep editing the outline as you start writing the paper, that's fine, but at some point you decide to stop doing the literature search  and actually start writing.  I wrote half of my master's thesis longhand while i was technically snow bound for 3 days in the middle of February by 9 inches of snow. Classes had been cancelled. i was fortunate.  I was the last graduate student my thesis adviser advised. I knew i wanted to do remote sensing based master's thesis, had even gotten a third bachelor's degree in geography because geography department did the remote sensing research and taught the remote sensing and aerial photography courses..  My thesis adviser was willing to advise as long as my study area was  the same as the area he is an recognized expert in.  I had no problems with that. The study area was one I could go to   in a reasonable amount of time and come back "home." in the same day.Because i am somewhat physically handicapped, my field truthing  was minimal.  Independent research is often based in curiosity, a question that YOU have and want to explore just because you are curious. How you organize your research, ESPECIALLY if your research NEEDS FUNDING, often dictates HOW you organize your research. My master's thesis did require  a work station. Fortunately my adviser  did have funding source so he could buy the Sun work station, which was later donated by him to school /department. as a server computer. Talk to your thesis or dissertation adviser, because USUALLY  a thesis or dissertation supports the  the adviser's research. Very few graduate students get to pick what kind of thesis  they want to do and find a faculty member who is willing to advise and sponsor them like i was able to. Yes,I DO have a personal research project that's usually on the "back burner" because it is in the data compilation stage. Yes, I HAVE discussed this with master's thesis adviser. I know I CANNOT afford the publication costs in a peer reviewed journal. Yes I did post some independent research as blog on the Digital Journal  in April 2008 because Katrina research. I wanted to figure out, again, because of natural curiosity, WHY my New orleans house DID NOT  FLOOD from the street when half or more of south Shore jefferson parish DID flood because of the Storm surge from Lake Pontchartrain and the open to air canals going over their banks. Other than that, my publications are three abstracts co-authored  with my thesis adviser.  in Geological Society of America abstracts. I'm not counting my master's thesis OR my  history honors thesis, even though both are bound  and in the Tulane  and University of Oklahoma library systems. I ENJOY doing library research. VERY few people enjoy doing library research, but i grew u[p reading Science, Scientific American and Time as bathroom reading material because i was a faculty dependent.

It is hard to discover new drugs. It is a long and expensive procedure to synthesize something.Companies that synthesize new components might only find one or two useful ones among thousands. And they have all the equipment to test the drugs.And even if a drug is useful, it might not be usable because the side effects or toxicity is too severe. These days most drug companies try to work with known mechanisms or do biochemical research first, and then try to design the drug to fit to the feature they want to change.Like you want to activate this specific receptor in the membrane:  So we figure out how the receptor works. Then we find the molecules that usually activates it. We then figure out how to make a more stable molecule that has the same activation site that fits with the receptor, but we also design it so we can administer the molecule as a drug. That means the designed molecule should both be stable, preferably water soluble, have the right activation site, mostly non-toxic and the body needs to be able to remove the molecule again.Alternatively we go out in the nature and find what plants, fungus and interesting animals synthesize to help themselves.But again we need a lot of work to find the molecules, figure out how they work and see if we can synthesize it ourselves, or need the organism to make it for us.Some of the best antibiotics are still grown by fungus, because it is too complicated to manufacture that molecule.  It is fun work, but I recommend at least a bachelor degree to be able to understand just some of the processes.And the equipment needed is expensive, so you should get a job in a laboratory to get access to the needed stuff. Remember to expect at least 5-8 years of work before you have any usable result. A test or procedure goes wrong half the time when you are experimenting or testing. And then you have to redo the work as you optimize your project... sigh... this is why I didn't want a Ph.D....

If researching by studying in a top university is a tough task, independently doing it could be more challenging. But since you are interested in doing it shows your curiosity in doing research. And that in itself is halfway through the arduous task of doing independent research. It would be best if you had the essential master’s degree in your study to do independent research. And the other fundamental requirement is to publish one or two articles of your niche in journals. It could be a turning point to gain the confidence to do independent research and successfully publish your research paper writing on your own. Tips for doing independent research and publishing it in a journal •Read, read, and read a lot on the topic selected for research from credible sources to obtain critical thinking to organize the research and write it •Get some fundamental ideas on how to go about the research and spend quality and quantity time on it to improve it better, exploring all the possibilities, testing them out, and finding the right one •Keep all the notes taken during the whole process of reading to refer it while writing the research paper •Identify a journal that publishes papers of the research domain and learn its specifications for publishing the paper •If possible, try to write the research paper as per the journal specifications along with the research for saving time to revise it again •Find the right online tools to facilitate research paper writing without errors and in the best way possible to make it good enough for publishing in the journals It takes a strong will and hard work for you to do research independently and publish it on your own, and it will surely reap its benefits. For further assistance, contact expert research paper writing services.

Basically, you would do up a research design. This would depend on the kind of research you want to conduct. Are you simply analyzing empirical research, reproducing an experiment or designing a new experiment? If you require a controlled study or a lab, you have those costs to factor in and time. You can outsource by contracting with a facility and you can hire a statistical service to help compile your data. What you'd need are the supervisors that can endorse your work and they are difficult to solicit as an independent researcher. Most researchers are already totally absorbed in their own projects. You coud talk to directors at your local university, however, and bring in your proposal to see if anyone "bites" but you have to have the feasibility study and projected budget done, plus a framework for the research and at least a cursory literature review. You also want to identify a legitimate publication ahead of time so you can publish your findings. Sometimes, if you've discovered significant preliminary findings on your own, you can submit your report to a funding ageny or institution and see if they will grant you funds and resources for additional research, which will only happen if your methodology is sound and your conclusions and observations can be verified. That's the idealistic scenario. If you go completely indie with it, you have to continuously cros-reference all your data yourself. If you have the passion and commitment and the time and resources, you could go solo and just publish and present.

All you really need is an email address, as long as you have the knowledge necessary to write a good paper and access to the scientific literature you need to put it into context. Just check the submission guidelines of the journal to which you want to submit the paper for details of how (and for details of what sort of papers they accept). Usually, the paper needs to be in a specified format and you can upload it through a web form. If you have never written a research paper before and are not working with someone with more experience, it is going to be very difficult to write a good paper. The leading journals accept only a few percent of the papers submitted, and even the middling journals accept less than half, though most of the submissions come from professional academics. So don't be disheartened if your paper is rejected - you will be in good company - and if it comes back with a lot of horrible criticisms and a request for "major revision", rejoice! That means the editor and reviewers are seriously considering your paper, if you make the changes they are asking for.

I would say that it would be very difficult if not impossible. Here is the thing scientific research involves few phases: 1) identify a problem 2) specify a theory that could explain this problem 3) devise an experiment that demonstrate (or invalidate) the solidity of the theory 4) describe the theory and results so your work can be evaluated by your peers  You see the point 4 is an important one. You need to explain and demonstrate  your theory to people that have enough knowledge to evaluate its work and either use it to further the research of your community or identify what you did wrong (no hard feelings it is is easy to miss some details). And this last point is as necessary as the 3 previous ones. Do note also that your problem and theory are also a consequence of what others did (you need to know if this problem was already addressed and how you theory improves previous ones) So you never really do research on your own: you are part of community and if you are not then, to me at least, you are not doing research but playing around in your little sandbox with nobody to tell you when you do something wrong.

I have done and published it that way. There was a time when I had no collaborator -- academic or professional, so in my free time (weekends, evenings or whatever), I kept working on some ideas. Later on, it came to a point where I thought it is probably a good idea to publish. I submitted to a conference and it got accepted, I self-funded my travel and conferenceregistration. In good journals, they don't charge you money - so you could directly submit there. There are 'Z' grade journals also, which charge you money and can publish any crap, but that's not probably you want. Basically, nobody cares, it you publish alone or with 25 people - if the work is good it will come up on its own. So, go for it...

Your profile shows you’re a physiotherapist, Ayobami Ayodele. Based on just that, and for the lack of any other information, I’ll suggest some general things you can start with. Perform meta-analyses. A lot of medical doctors publish meta-analysis research papers, which involves systematic collection and quantification of medical information, either from medical records or previously published research, and integrating it all to derive conclusions that can affect clinical procedures and practices. If done well can be published in very high-impact journals. Perhaps this is something you can adapt to your situation as well?Write a critical review of the literature already published. You can start by reading good journals in your field, and perhaps formulate an idea for a good review article, concerning the latest advances.Read journal articles to see how other physiotherapists formulate an idea and what kind of resources they need to publish. Perhaps you can adapt some of those to your practice or the cases you come across. Reading more may help you find a gap in literature, a question that you can design a study around.If you work in a hospital or a university, find senior fellows who you can associate with and assist them in their projects.Good luck!

A2A I've been researching on the side for about 3 years. How I've done it is in my free time, about 8 hrs a week, mostly on weekends. Just find time to do it if it's a passion. Publishing is the same as if you were in a group. Just get a good result, write it up, and submit it. It's helpful to have an official association with somewhere, but not necessary (unusual). My work was done at a local university which granted me Adjunct status so on my current submission, I'm associated with that school. Currently the manuscript is in the 2nd-ish round of review. At least it has been sent out for peer review which exemplifies that what you are asking is, indeed, doable. Hopefully I can make it official from experience soon :)

You want to be sure that both the content and style match that of the journal.  In the social sciences and humanities, in particular, there are often different philosophical paradigms that dominate particular journals, and you need to notice where the journal stands in that sense. So see if people have written on your specialty topic previously in the journal, and if the general philosophical and methodological orientation of the journal matches yours.   Particularly valuable: Check whether your own article's references are also published or referenced in the journal.  Chances are, some of those people will be reviewing your article for the journal.  Have you cited all the relevant people in the field whose work relates to yours?  If you were a reviewer for them, how would you feel if they failed to cite your work?

…or forget about journals altogether. Self-publishing is a reality in the academic world as well. There have been free archives where researchers can post their articles since the early nineties (see arXiv) and now some of these archives also offer open, community-based peer review (see sjscience.org). Commercial journals still exist for the prestige that goes associated with their brand, which helps in career advancement and funding. But if you are not interested in playing this game, you can publish your researcher and get reviews from expert peers that will help you improve your ideas and methods, without having to prostitute your intelectual property to commercial publishers with 30–40% profit margins…

The biggest problems are financing and affiliation. It would be impossible for you to do "wet" biological research if you don't have a lab and grants to fund it. But you may try something like theoretical biology, computational biology, mathematics etc. Those things don't require a lab and a lot of funding. Still, most journal editors will be surprised if you don't have a PhD and are not affiliated with any research institution or university. They will ask themselves: who's that guy? And will probably reject your paper without even sending for peer review. So, try to get an affiliation. And I of course assume you have the skills to do research, time to do it, and have some other source of income to sustain your living.

By just doing it.  Institution affiliation has nothing to do with it (unless you are researching something like brain transplants for children). In some areas there is narrowminded prejudice against non-institutionalised research and it might be helpful to state your address as "Credible Name Research Institute" to do a bit to counter this, though some won't be fooled anyway if they know all the people in the field anyway.   Beware that the system can be prejudiced against you too.  You will see that all the papers in Personality and Individual Differences have the important indexing in PubMed, with the sole exception of my own 2015 effort, despite it having gone through the "peer review" like all the others.  This is just due to a PubMed policy that they will index only those papers which were pre-supported by institutional grants, nothing to do with merit given that there is the "peer review" anyway. I don't know anything about computer "science" field so won't reply to your other question.

Thanks for A2A, but, it's probably easier to provide you with advice if you specify where your current expertise lies and then people could suggest pathways to close the gaps. For example, are you a chemist who is currently working in the pharmaceutical industry, but, you are unsure about how to conduct research trials? Or, are you currently involved in designing and conducting medical research and now want to become more involved in clinical pharmacology? To be honest, it will be difficult to switch from your current area of expertise to a field that is largely unrelated but don't let anyone tell you it's impossible. It may require that you complete another PhD - I'm assuming you have one already - but that would be the price of becoming your own drug laboratory and clinical trial centre.

Considering you probably have already carried out some sort of research in the field of mechanical engineering and are keen on publishing it, the way forward would be to search for a relevant journal on the internet that accepts papers in the domain of your research.Once you have found it, you would only need to follow the steps listed on their website to submit the research paper following certain guidelines which are unique to each journal. Some potential places where you can look for suitable journals are:SAE International Engineering Standards News and Resources for Engineers - ASME Elsevier is a world-leading provider of scientific, technical and medical information products and services Springer - International Publisher Science, Technology, Medicine

I'm not aware of any restrictions regarding 'doing research';  the issue may arise when you attempt to publish in a note worthy, relevant journal however- they like to see a track record, or at least co-authorship with University creds. If your work utilizes animal research beyond mice and rats, than special (Federal, State, Local)  licences may be required.    The recent advent of fast and easy genetic modification 'tools' has yet to raise any impacting concerns, but I suspect that will change when someone makes a mistake.

1) Is this trip really necessary?  Before spending the effort getting a journal article published, try to figure out *why* you want the article published.  The big reason people publish in journals is to advance their academic careers.  Since you don't have an academic career, you need to understand why you are doing it. 2) Get co-authors.   3) If you can't get co-authors then find a group of people that will grind the paper into dust before you submit to the journal. 4) Don't be independent.  You need to network.  You need to attend conferences.  You need to show up an seminars.  You need to teach.

The first thing to do is to identify some questions in economics that interest you. Then star reading what has been done in to address this issue. At this point you can start to formulate a question to answer. Economists tend to rely on math, statistics and/or data as part of their research. Without these tools, it will be difficult. However, you can do some rsearch based on interviews. My high school students use  the COBWEB software, which is fee,ly available through the University Research Experience in Complex Systems)to simulate retail clusters and the impact of transportation costs on land use/density.  To conclude,mint is possible to begin research in economics but you do need to put in some time to get started. It is possible to proceed without a mentor, but it will be more difficult.

Not easy but it can be done. I published my first paper in J Membrane Biol in 1982. I did not show it to anyone. When I got the referee’s comments back I showed them to my PhD supervisor and he helped me revise it and it got accepted. I published 5 papers single authored out of my PhD and 5 with my supervisor where he was second author. I published a paper with my fear-less leader this year. He is still sharp. On my Research Gate website I have a Masters course which I taught on “How to Publish papers in International Journals”. You might find it of value. Beware of predatory academics such as Prof Insectivorous Bullfrog who live off exploiting naive students who think they must have a coauthor to publish.

Do you have a new novel idea in your field which you think matters?? The first thing to do is to improve upon the topic by taking a literature survey which is nothing but a collection of articles which you use for reference. These articles or similar research papers are the reference column that you put at the back of your paper. The next process is developing the idea by experimenting and validating it. If you are in CS and if you have made a new phenomenal code , then test the code and if it gives results then that's proper validation. The final step is Writing the paper itself which you can turn to your professor to. Good luck :)

Its like decision is made for independent research, now question is how to? Research, study and understand your topic very well, know its requirements, sources, hurdles, plan, write down, make every note regarding it as you only make mistake and you only can solve it. Be prepared to solve accordingly. The single most important thing to become an independent researcher is Funding depending upon countries. For that would suggest to start small and take calculated risk. To publish, start writing review articles at beginning of your research itself through which you can know deeper in your topic of interest and your one paper will be ready for publication. Bring your article to a quality and start from high impact factors journals to communicate, learn and keep improving from rejections.
This is why you go to graduate school, so you learn how to do independent research.

If you have a research methodology training you can always do it on your own. Find a research question search literature and mount on it. You can access library and internet. The problem is you won't get funding. To resolve that you can start small projects do it on your own, publish them and sinultaneously establish a small scale organisation get funding from different sources. There are ample evidences of people doing research successfully and independently. Moreover, research in itself is an independent and often lonely but lovely affair!

It's entirely possible but difficult and probably expensive.  Without the financial backing of a university or research institute you need to pay for access to journals and conference proceedings so that you have the relevant research papers to back up your assertions.  You may also have to pay to submit a paper to a journal.  Unless you are already experienced in writing research papers you will struggle to get a paper published as it is a skill that must be learned.

Depends on which field you wanna research.. for research on living organisms u need proper permission and ethical clearance..for mathematics etc you can do without clearance.. search for papers on related topics.. take care research is not repeated one.after you are done with your experiments and got a conclusion you can write it as a research paper are searched send it for publication to reputed journal of same field..

Do your research in the way any other researcher would and submit your paper in the usual way. If the quality is right, it'll get published. You don't need co-workers or supervisors, but they are an important source of feedback and advice and will help you avoid dead ends or pitfalls. It's like learning a musical instrument — it can be done solo but it's easier with a guide!

First off all you have to choose topic of your own interest. There are a number of options available such as datamining, cloud computing, networking, security, cryptography etc. Then a number of simulation tools such as Matlab, NS2 etc are available for implementation and results purpose. After gaining results you can write your research paper. You can findout a number of published research paper for your reference on www.ijritcc.org.

Without any lab facilities you couldn't start doing any project work. Even I thought the same. My suggestion is just join with one PhD scholar and help them, and in that you can publish your part of work. Else do writing a review paper, that will also work. Here am completed my masters, but need one paper to pursue my PhD. My case is different. So now am writing a review paper. So same way you can also choose. All the best..:)

I have reviewed for journals that do not do double blind reviewing, i.e. they include the authors' names and affiliations on manuscripts to be reviewed. So this is something you may want to be aware of before submitting to any particular journal as I'm sure it makes a difference to many reviewers, if only subconsciously.
For doing Research independently you need to secure a tenured position in an reputed university and then apply for grants.
